title: AAA Battery Holder for Wall / Door mounting

description.text: Holds 20 AAA batteries. This holder is designed with a cavity behind which I used to set the mounting system to the door. I placed it onto the door of a cabinet so the that the batteries are available on opening the door. To connect it to the door I used 3M Dual Lock. This is the greatest stuff and worth purchasing if you don't already have some. It is essentially velcro on steroids. The adhesive backing on this stuff is permanent and heavy duty. See http://solutions.3m.com/wps/portal/3M/en_US/Adhesives/Tapes/Products/~/3M-Dual-Lock-Reclosable-Fastener-SJ3870?N=5927706+3294281433&rt=rud for more details. The gap in the back will perfectly fit the Dual Lock so that the unit sits flush with the wall or door that it is mounted on.

description.text:
3 people
4 people
6 people
would appreciate it if you print this please let me know,

VertiBOT is an educational project to investigate and understand sensor fusion using kalman and complementary filter algorithm and PID control in an unstable system. VertiBOT is an inverted pendulum platform that remains balanced by means of two tiny motors, located in the bottom of the structure. The battery is attached in the top of the main body, while the electronics board is located near the rotation axis.
The feedback signal is provided by an IMU 6Dof composed by an accelerometer and a gyro. One ATmega 328 microcontroller execute the main loop every 10 milliseconds. A wireless communication over bluetooth is used to tune and check the signal response in a Graphical User Interface software. Video: http://youtu.be/A5KtT4GVpx8
Useful info, schematic and code available: http://wp.me/p22sj0-fT

• Microcontroller ATmega 328 16MHz (Arduino nano).
  • IMU 6Dof: accelerometer y gyroscope.ADXL345/ ITG3200
  • Motor Driver Pololu Qik2sv1.
  • Bluetooth modem for wireless communication.
  • Potentiometer for PID tuning parameters
  • Buttons for different tasks: algorithm change, calibration offsets ..
  • Voltage regulator (MCP1700) and logic converter .
  • Pololu MicroMetal Motors (50:1)
  • Pololu Wheels 90x10mm

title: DANO NODA COSMETICS – industrial packaging rapid prototyping

description.text:
For PrintCity (a marketing federation for the printing and packaging industry) I made a packaging design for a virtual brand to show and educate the industry about possibilities of inline production of high decorated value added folding boxes (using a gallus ICS 670 modular printing system).  
For the final step I decided to construct and print a perfect integrated cosmetic pot for that folding box (based on the diamond shape) with perfect fit and made for industrial processing. I made this to find the perfect fitting flacon design for that box but also for the first marketing images of the whole project. All parts – including the perfect closing screwed locks – are made individually by me using CAD-Software without any parts-library.  
Feel free to print this sample pot for your own personal use (please respect the Non-Commercial license).   
The folding box packaging samples can get requested (assuming for free) at www.printcity.de

The cosmetic pot is made out of three different materials per sample and I used PLA Black for the stand, PET for the Body and PLA yellow and pink for the cap.  
All parts are printed with Ultimaker 2.  
The sample prints on that images were made with 1.6 mm shell thickness (25 % infill) for the stand and 100 mm shell thickness for body and cap to let Cura reduce infill to a minimum (important for the translucent PET) and give the cap a perfect finish on the upper layer (Cura switches to spiral square pattern instead of diagonal lines which in this case fits better to the diamond shape of the whole object).   
I printed the parts with 0.1 mm resolution for the stand, 0.12 mm for the PET Body and 0.06 mm for the cap. Stand is printed without support, cap and body (upside down!) are printed with support from print table only with 2 mm distance from the surface to not touch/destroy the screwes.  
I also decided to use the parts without extra finishing because that surface fits best to the design (body looks a bit like a rough diamond).

title: 6x9 film holder for scanning
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Yeah, some us are still using film but we have to digitize it to share it. The film holders that come with some scanners are Teh SuXXor so I made a couple in InkScape that should make my life easier. And why not share that?

It's a pretty simple piece and anyone who scans or works with film should see how it goes together: essentially it's two frames with pair of guides to keep the film centered in the frame. I recommend the thinnest material you can find that will offer enough strength to work with film that wants to curl or cup.

title: Yuneec Q500 Typhoon GoPro Style Gimbal Adapter Plate

description.text:
I designed a Gimbal Adapter Plate that will allow you to use a GoPro or GoPro Style Action Camera with your Yuneec Q500 Typhoon. How to install:
  • Remove your CGO2 Camera carefully
  • Separate the top Plate from the Gimbal Adapter
  • Assemble GoPro Plate with original top Plate via the Vibration Dampers
  • Add your Camera and install back onto the Yuneec Q500 Tyhpoon
    • P.S. Alternatively you can buy a replacement Mount Set for around $10 which will give you the Top Plate and Vibration Dampers so you don't have to take the Stock one apart the Part # is YUNCGO2GB102

author: Looney

description.text: Inspired by Sneakypoo's work, I ended up remodeling from scratch to make this. It's a handy pair of... jaws?... for holding PCBs during soldering or other work. Also discussed here: http://www.makersite.com/blog/2013/5/2/magnetic-pcb-holder-nylon-printed

Slice 'n' Print! I used Nylon but ABS or PLA would be fine. After slicing, visualize the gcode (using Netfabb or Pleasant3D or similar) and figure out where you need to pause it to drop your magnets in. I use Sailfish firmware and use the Pause and ZPos feature.  
The cavities meant to hold the magnets begin to be capped off at a height 3.34mm above the base plane (assuming you're orienting as I did for printing). That should help you decide where to pause... but do double check, as there are sometimes tricks about starting elevations, etc., depending on the slicer settings. (Thanks, Austin!)  
The magnets are neodymium, very strong, 0.5" diameter x 0.1" thick disks.

comments.text: I don't know how many times it's possible to do this, but I emailed their support, and selected replacement parts(or something to that effect) as the reason for contacting them.  I told them they started cracking around a year or so after I had purchased them, and that only just recently, about 2.5 years after purchase, did they start falling apart.  They asked for a shipping address and shipped the replacements out.
comments.author: MooTaters

comments.text: Look up 'planned obsolescence'... We live in a world where capitalism has run wild and greed shows no end. Things are designed specifically to break at controlled time frames in order to increase profits. 3d printing is our way of shifting the status quo back in favor of the consumer and the environment.
comments.author: MooTaters

comments.text: Trust me, I know about planned obsolescence, and there are plenty of products where it's hardly a thing or the warranty makes it a non-problem.  Computer power supplies for example, it's not difficult at all to find one with a 5+ or even 7+ year warranty.  And yet unless when building a new PC you sell off the full set of old parts and build a 100% brand new one, that PSU could last you a good 10 years.  I know my old one lasted 7+ years, by around 7 years I sold it to a friend along with other parts, and that was before such long warranties were a thing.  And that's a product in quite the niche market, granted I'm sure they have a healthy enough profit margin on them.
comments.author: Quixotic

comments.text: My headphones Sliders cracked, and finally cracked so bad that the left hand side fell apart, and I was holding it together with electrical tape.  Spare parts from Germany was listed at 17.5 Euro.  Spareparts within Australia was $AU60. (40euro).   I sent the STL file to a local 3Dprinter guy via 3Dhubs, and the cost for two sets (8 pieces of plastic) was $AU12.50.  Fantastic.  I sent you DKK35 for a cup of coffee :) thanks very much for making this so easy to find (correct name of part) and free to download.
comments.author: ExcessionOz

comments.text: Really glad to be of service :) Thank you very much for the coffee, I am an addict when it comes to the black magic. Coffee helps me code, design and exist in general.

Thanks for designing this slider piece, its a great alternative than having to fork out on the original spare parts.
Just wondering though, what do you think of having a shallow channel/groove cut out on the rear panel (i.e the piece which the screws enter from) so that the cable that runs from left to right earcups via the headband, can be placed in.
Ideally the channel/groove would be placed near centre, but if that area is too thin on material (compromising its strength) then perhaps where it is more thicker.

This design is a simple container which is sized for an Alum shaving stone. It features a built in stand with drip slots in the bottom and a press fit lid.  
I've included the design files in 123D format so that it can be resized for different applications.

In the container pictured, I printed the container itself in ABS and the lid in PLA - the only reason for this was to get the different colours, not for any technical reason!  
Print the container upside down and use support - this will ensure that the drip holes are nice and clean.  
The lid should also be printed upside down, but doesn't require any support.

title: Cat Food Ball
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This ball is intended to give your cat exercise as they eat their food.
I saw a ball like this at the pet store and, as I have extremely strong makerbot goggles, decided to design and print one.
It's taken her a while, but my cat is starting to learn to use it.

You will need your support settings dialed in properly for these prints. It will take some excavating after as well, but they turn out nicely.
Fill one half with dry food, and push the other half on. The two halves press fit together with some minor sanding, though you may not even need that.

An assembly that takes a standard rotary encoder and adds the ability to sense when the encoder is pushed in 4 directions. It also supports a center button if it is built in to the rotary encoder without activating any of the other directions. It does this by having a disc that holds the rotary encoder balance on a cone in the bottom holder. This will allow it to rotate along the X and Y axis enough to push buttons on the top of the assembly. This is the first part I designed to be printed and is for a small raspberry pi and xbmc based kitchen radio/viewer so most functions could be performed with one knob. Other Parts:
Rotary Encoder: PEC11-4220F-S0024, Newark #02J2850 I'm not sure what the part number is for the push buttons used, but they have a base of 6.5mm squared and the full height with the button not pressed is 5.0mm. The lower limit of the switch makes the height 4.75mm

Print all three parts. Depending on your printer, you may need to clean up the parts to make sure there are no stringers and the surfaces are smooth. When I printed the center rotary encoder holder, I could not get the bottom indent to print correctly, so I corrected it with a dremel. Assemble the parts temprarily to make sure the center holder can move up, down, left, and right, but not rotate along the Z axis. Attach four small push buttons to the bottom of the lid. I used hot glue in this case, which seems to work well so far. Make sure leads are point out. Solder wires on the rotary encoder and feed the wires through the holes in the holder. Glue in place. Feed the encoder's wires through the holes in the bottom container and make sure the holder can still move. It may help putting a layer of masking tape between the bottom container and the holder. This will make the holder stay center and provide a better feel in the completed unit. Attach the top to the bottom container using 4x M3x20 screws and nuts. The holes may need to be drilled a bit wider if the print was not accurate. Finally, solder wires to the four push buttons and connect them to your board as you would any other switch. You should now feel satisfying clicks when moving the encoder up down left and right. If it is too tight, you can place washers between the bottom and top components until you get all four buttons in the open state when not pushing the encoder. Enjoy and happy hacking!
-Leo

remixed_from.title: PrintrBot Simple X-axis GT2 Belt & Extension

description.text:
Based on Ahaer's great model, modified for the 1405 and for properly sized rods so nothing's sticking out annoyingly. This will extend your x-axis safely to 155mm. This way, the auto level probe still functions.  
Will print on the stock simple with some careful rotating!  
I just ended up wrapping the gt2 belt around the small toothed portion where it's suppossed to slot in for ease. This seems to work more than fine. Additionally, I only zip tied the bed down so the extruder head didn't smash into the nuts (found that out the hard way!)

You'll probably have to drill out the holes for the rods with a 5/8" bit and the holes for the nuts (if you choose to use them, but be careful!) with a 7/64" bit. Other than that, make sure to send M211 X155 Y100 Z100 followed by M500 to change the printer shape. Make sure to update everything in repetier and slicer as well.

Inspired, but designed from scratch.

Green Cape (New South Wales, Australia) O scale (1:48) lighthouse model printed in eight different pieces assembled together. The full scale model is 60 cm. high and it was designed based in the original blueprints.
The model is complemented with an analog electronic circuit to simulate real life operation. The custom circuit design is included. Watch the model operation:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YqM7jzCCSrY The circuit has three different functions: It drives a 12V automotive led bulb as the main light; The red beacon on top of the dome, and the interior lighting.
Each model piece can be painted before assembly with regular spray paint to match the original building.

The prototype was printed in white PLA with 0.2 mm slice height.
It is better to print the Base and Body pieces on a heated bed to avoid distortion and print the Balcony and Optics pieces at slow speed. No support is necessary.
There are two Balcony and Optics2 files, you must choose the one suited for your printer's capabilities. The Optics2b part includes support rods that need to be removed manually after printing.
The Body3 file is inverted so it can be printed without support

comments.text: The electric components are common ones. Where to buy them depends mainly on your residence country. The main LED bulb can be found in an Auto Parts Shop (see Peggy's Cove lighthouse for details) and the rest of the pieces in an Electronics Shop like Radio Shack (in the US) or Steren (in Mexico, where I live).

comments.text:
Thanks for your comment!!
I've just downloaded body part 3 and it looks fine in Cura, maybe your file downloaded corrupt or your slicing program settings were not optimal. Try to downloaded again and use at least 3 perimeters for the outside walls and 20% infill.
Regarding the thickness of the lower body parts, you're right, but my intention was to have a uniform circular gallery in the inside (as the real construction has) to locate the electronics. Try to lower the infill settings as much as you can to save some material.
Regards.

remixed_from.title: Left and Right Hand Quartz Crystals

description.text: Here is a quartz crystal model meant to be a teaching aid.  One version is labeled and the faces identified.  A second version lacks labels and has faces large enough so that the interfacial angles can be measured with a simple protractor.  A brief description of the model and how to use it is in Angles.txt.  OpenSCAD code is included.
Inexpensive protractors can be purchased from building supply stores like The Home Depot or Lowes.  Results accurate to plus or minus a degree are easily obtained.

description.text:
L'astroinseguitore è stato progettato per inseguire il moto apparente delle stelle causato dalla rotazione terrestre, eliminando così le strisciate stellari tipiche delle fotografia a lunga posa non inseguite.
L'astroinseguitore può essere usato anche come testa Pan (o Tilt) per foto panoramiche The Barn door trackers is designed to track the apparent motion of stars caused by the Earth's rotation, thus eliminating the scrapes typical of stellar photography long exposure not pursued. The Barn door trackers can also be used as head Pan (or Tilt) for panoramic photos

Altro materiale occorrente:
N° 1 motore passo passo con riduttore 100:1
http://www.omc-stepperonline.com/gear-ratio-1001-planetary-gearbox-with-nema-11-stepper-motor-11hs200674spg100-p-36.html
N° 2 Cuscinetti 6002
CM 30 tubo alluminio 15x1
N°1 Puleggia 18 denti XL 037
N°1 Puleggia 45 denti XL 037
N° 1 Cinghia dentata 120 XL 037 Per la parte di comando:
n° 1 Arduino Nano
n° 1 StepStick
n° 1 LCD 20x4 I2C
n° 1 Tastiera mebrana 4x1
n° 1 Fotoaccoppiatore 4n35
n° 4 resistenze da 10 Kohm
n° 1 resistenza da 68 ohm
n° 1 Circuito stampato MamoUnit Con questa configurazione, si ottiene una risoluzione di :
Motoriduttore = 200 x 99,05 = 19810
Pulegge = 45 / 18 = 2.5
In pratica per fare un giro completo ci vogliono 19810 x 2,5 = 49525 step
Risoluzione = 360° / 49525 = 0,00727° circa Rotazione terrestre = 23 h 56 min 4 s
Trasformati in millisecondi = 86.164.000
Quindi uno step ogni
86164000 / 49525 = 1739,808 ms

comments.text:
Hi Mamo,
did you compare this to Barn Door Trackers with more classic designs? They have much bigger leverage witch should lead to better accuracy, but your design is so slick that I'm very interested in it. How long exposures (and with what focal length) were you able to achieve?
Keep up a great work :)
comments.author: roolin

comments.text:
Hello Roolin,
My project, unlike the classic barndoor, uses the precision of the stepper motor coupled to a gear which allows for more precise movements because the gear further reduces the displacement for each step.
The limit of this solution is stability.
With a standard tripod (Manfrotto 190) the focal maximum you can use is around 70 mm. If you exceed this value, the system vibrates too.
With a more stable tripod you push yourself a little more.

comments.author: laudix

comments.text:
Ciao Salvatore.
Non ho preso in considerazione l'utilizzo dei microstep per il semplice motivo che utilizzandoli devi continuamente tenere in tensione il motore.
Questo comporta un uso molto più intenso della batteria.
Per mantenere il motore in una certa posizione (e con i microstep è così) devi alimentare il motore stesso. A livello di consumo di energia, è come se il motore (anche se fermo) girasse.
Per quanto riguarda la velocità (1 impulso ogni 1738 contro i tuoi 5385) dipende dall'obbiettivo che colleghi alla macchina.
Se è un grandangolo spinto credo che non ci siano problemi.
Se invece è un piccolo zoom, allora credo che non vada bene. In 5 secondi le stelle possono muoversi molto velocemente.
Prova a simulare il cielo che vuoi fotografare. Metti l'obbiettivo che vorresti usare e prova ad inquadrare il cielo. Se in 5 secondi, il cielo resta "fermo" allora puoi provare la tua soluzione.
In questo modo puoi verificare anche la stabilità del tuo cavalletto. Con zoom molto spinti è essenziale un sistema molto stabile.

The software part still have to develop, but not a big problem.

description.text: Place two continuous rotation servo motors, and Arduino Mini, a 3 AAA battery case, and a long range Sharp IR sensor into the print job mid print. This is still a work in progress, so I am still working out some of the bugs. Read about how to set this up here: https://printeraction.wordpress.com/2015/05/16/print-out/ Or watch here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mp0pQyzSg4Q Code is available here:

The code for this is available here: https://github.com/printeraction/Build-Plate-Walkers/blob/master/Build%20Plate%20Walker%201 View the full instructions here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mp0pQyzSg4Q Or read how to do it here: https://printeraction.wordpress.com/2015/05/16/print-out/ Don't use support material. Once the top "segment" of the print has nearly begun, place a 3 AAA battery box, arduino mini, two continuous rotation servo motors, and a long range Sharp IR sensor into the print. Then plate the "covering" piece over all components to give the rest of the print a flat surface to print on top of.

description.text:
This is a GoPro case designed to keep my Hero4 shaded from the sun when hiking the lava fields in Hawaii or when ATVing in the desert. I printed it out of white ABS plastic to help reflect the the sun and keep the GoPro cool. There is a border around the lens where a laser cut piece of plexiglass will go to protect the  waterproof housing lens.  
This case is meant for the Hero3 standard case or the new dive case, however the slimmer Hero3+ case and Hero4 Case should work as well with some extra gap around the edges.  
My next version will include active cooling and heating using a peltier device and an Arduino nano

I didn't make this, just converted it from here:
http://thefree3dmodels.com/stuff/characters/elizabeth/14-1-0-5306 Have fun. I know I will.

Converted from .obj to .stl using MeshLab.  
I've never used a 3D printer or related software before, so I have no idea what the scale is. It could be huge, or tiny. I don't know.

title: Subaru front door speaker adapter plates

description.text:
These are used to hold aftermarket speakers. These replace the factory mounts directly in the front driver/passenger doors. I have been using these with Pioneer TS-D1602R 6.5" in a 2003 Subaru Legacy for months with no issues.  
I don't know which vehicles these are compatible with, but I would expect many Subarus are compatible!  
Features ABS recycling logo from Michigan Tech's MOST lab. I would recommend printing in ABS due to its flexibility (see the instructions tab).

Print in ABS and run around the screw holes with a little bit of acetone to ensure good bonding. The screws dig in a little bit! Also, before installing, make sure layer adhesion is adequate. This part is very sensitive to bad layer adhesion, and you don't want that speaker bouncing around in your door after a few hours of use...

description.text:
This a GoPro camera tray I designed for scuba diving in Vancouver. The base pieces were waterjet cut out of aluminum and the handles were lathed. I designed some washers that lock into the groove and allow positioning of various GoPro's and lights. This print may be ideal for the carbon fiber filament as it requires a stiff material for the base.   
The handles are designed to fit standard mountain biking lock-on grips.  
All holes and slots are meant for standard 1/4-20 bolts used for tripods.
10-Oct-2015: Added Sports Finder STL file
These blocks are designed to fit with 3/16 (0.1875) dowels. I do a lot of simple prototyping with that size of dowels and these blocks are good if you want to build erector set type structures.

title: TTKit - Tactical Toolbox Kit
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A small box to hold all the tools you would need in a basic, or advance field-repair. Mount it on you belt.   
You'll need to glue the "Belt_clip" to the back. The lock is mounted with a screw. The hole in the lock is a little bigger than the hole in the bottom,  
The "Tool_Mount" and the "Tool_Holder" parts, needs to be scaled to the individual tool, and then glued into the wished position. The diameter on the holes are 5 mm.  
I would not recommend using hot glue. Its too weak, and takes up space. Use something like Contact-glue, or superglue. Just be careful! Do this at your own risk! Are you underage, get an adult to help.

comments.text: Nice I like the idea as well as your clip design... Tools are always good to have around.  I have tried a few times without success to make a good belt clip, I might print yours to see how well it works :D

description.text:
These are some housings for the RADDS / Arduino-Due LCD Display.
The fit on 2020 or 1515 Kossel.
For those who don't have the typical setup with two parallel, horizontal extrusions on their (non-kossel) printer, I made a "Mono" version. Credits go to user mundsen (http://www.thingiverse.com/mundsen) for providing the STLs of the RADDS hardware.

I've printed all parts with 0.1 mm layers on bare glass (@ 60°C).
The three screws for the pushbuttons don't need to be tightend firmly - some play is wanted, as they only hold the two buttons in place.

title: Clamp for desk lamp/magnifier. SCad file and STL

description.text:
Clamp for desk lamp/magnifier. SCad file and STL Someone gave me an old desk lamp with magnifying glass
but it didn't have the clamp on base. So I designed and printed one, and here it is.

I used Slic3r make my gcode.
I found printing it at 60% with honeycomb and 8 solid layers
at .25mm worked best for my printer.
The final print was done with the clamp in an upright position with support. This made it stronger than laying on its side. I used an M8 nut and bolt, you will need to adjust all the sizes for your purposes.

description.text: It's a Toy! If I remember correctly my first attempt was 10x10x10 mm blocks and 10x10 mm beams. With my Up! Mini printer being 200 micron this did not work out so well. This design is scaled up to 20x20x20 mm blocks attached to 20x20 mm beams. If this does not work I will scale up to 30x30.

Well this is my first thing, and first off I wanted to say this is a derivative of hugepedlar's Meat Boy at thingiverse.com/thing:7702 & Voxelous' version voxelo.us/products.html . I liked their versions but I wasn't a fan of the serious fan that Volexous and he used. That being said I made a slightly different one, from pictures on google. I built off of hugepedlars stls, but made some modifications to the pieces such as:
  • The hands (made them a bit wider & set them higher, more correct to the official character models)
  • The feet (made them a bit taller, more correct to voxelous version)
  • The face (adding eyebrows and a cheek effect to show off the smile.)
  • Added some eyes to fill in if you have some black ABS to use
    • I used google sketchup as best as I could, you'll notice there are teeth made, but they don't show up in the for some reason. Maybe some of you can find the reason...I like my results which is why I didn't list this as a work in progress. Voxelous' version is superior due to the method of printing that they use, so if you really like this print go on ahead to their site and buy the official ones when they're back in stock. I will do the same... voxelo.us/products.html
Simply print, clean when needed, and fit into slots. Glue might be needed to have them hold in place... I used a glue gun, as I didn't have any other glues with me

description.text:
Large delta printer for ceramic extrusion. Extruding clay:
https://vimeo.com/128022387
Homing:
https://vimeo.com/128063275

Larger delta printer for extruding clay. The Moineau Pump extruder is capable of controlled volume per motor step. Uses:
1/2 in diameter rods for the towers.
Nema 17 60mm stepper motors for each axis
Nema 17 34mm stepper motors for the extruder
5mm diameter rods for the arms
608 skate bearings for the carriages Clay recipe used:
35% kaolin
25% ball clay
20% nepheline syenite
20% silica Add: deflocculant about 1% (sodium silicate, soda ash, or darvan 7)

description.text: The water limiting button on my 18 years old Grohe faucet failed because some small part on the inside of the knob was broken.  I designed a ring in Openscad to put inside the knob and replace the broken part.  Probably you will need to modify the design to adjust for the broken parts in your knob.  This is v2 of the design, because in the first one, the parts on the 2nd level of the ring broke off very easily because the 2nd level needed to start in the middle of a 0.2mm layer.  Now the 2nd level starts at a multiple of 0.2mm.  If you need or want to print in a different layer height, then you may need to adapt the layer height in de scad file.
Printed in ABS @ 0.20mm layer height and 40% 3D Honeyconb infill.

description.text:
DIY pet wheelchair, using 3D printed connectors and aluminum bars. See it in action here:
https://youtu.be/pwSwQdUgAic I'm developing a cheap DIY wheel chair, that's can be easily customized and scaled to fit any disabled pet. There are three 3D printed parts, and each needs to be printed in two copies (some files already have both copies aligned): HortiVerticalAdapter (X2) - This piece connects the width bar with the two length bars. WheelFrameBandConnector - This piece sits on the length bars and connects each to a wheel bar. It's also the basis for the rear saddle. BuckleConnector - This also sits on the length bars, and is designed to connect to a buckle, which will attach the wheel chair to your pet's harness. The original dimensions of these 3D printed parts are designed to work with 1cm wide, 3mm thick bars. The two length bars and the two wheel bars are 30cm long, and the width bar is 20cm long. EDIT: I added new files that should fit nicely with 12mm aluminum bars as requested (it appears 12mm is much commoner and easier to acquire in Australia. Cheers!).

The inch version of these calipers has a direct-read scale with 0.1" markings and a secondary micrometer-style scale that reads down to 0.001"!  (Yeah, right...)   Realistically, it's maybe accurate to +/-0.010".  
The metric version has a direct-read scale with 2mm markings and a secondary scale with 0.1mm graduations.

UPDATE: A metric version has been added! The same slider part is used for both.
  • For metric, use the parts: body_mm.stl, nut_mm.stl, dial_mm.stl and slider.stl.
  • For imperial, use the parts: body_in.stl, nut_in.stl, dial_in.stl and slider.stl.
    • These parts were printed in PLA with 0.2mm layers, 3 perimeters and 20% infill. If you don't have a heated bed, you should print the body and slider parts with a raft to make sure they are flat. You should print them fairly slowly to retain as much detail as possible. After printing, you'll probably need to lightly sand some of the parts, particularly the inside threads on the nut, to remove any lumps. To Assemble:
  • Test fit the dial on the nut. You want it to have some friction so that it takes a little effort to rotate it. Sand down the ID if it is too tight, add a little scotch tape if it is too loose.
  • Pinch the ears on the slider together and push then into the nut. Once they are started, screw the nut onto the ears until it snaps into place.
  • Apply a little grease or vaseline to the outer threads on the body. Slide the slider onto the body and start screwing on the nut. At first, the nut will be pretty tight, but as you work it back & forth along the entire length of the body, it should loosen up.
  • Close the calipers almost all the way. Take a piece of 120 grit (or so) sand paper and clamp it lightly with the grit side facing the nub on the fixed jaw. Slide the sandpaper back & forth to hone the surface of the nub parallel to the moving jaw.
  • Before using, close all the way until you can't see any light between the fixed nub and the moving jaw. Hold the nut stationary and rotate the dial so that it reads "0". As the threads wear, you may need to re-zero the calipers.

title: Removable landing gear and wheels for Bixler 2

description.text: This is a removable undercarriage for Bixler / Bixler 2. I´ve included some wheels too.

You don´t need any support to print this item. It has been designed to be used with M5 screws. Needed for front landing gear:
-1 x Main piece (3D printed)
-1 x front stiffener (3D printed, must be glued to main piece)
-2 x Wheels (Big or small, as you like, 3D printed)
-2 x M5 (16 mm at least)
-2 x M5 nuts.
-2 bearings (10x5x4 - External, inner and thickness)
-1 x rubber if you don´t want to glue it to the plane. Needed for Gear landing rear:
-1 x Main rear piece
-1 x Wheel 3 mm (3D printed)
-1 x M3 screw (16 mm at least)
-1 x M3 nut.
-1 x Rubber if you don´t want to glue it to the plane. Changes and updates: -2015-05-16 - First Design.
-2015-05-17 - Added rear landing gear and 3 mm. Wheel for it. Uploaded a stiffener for preventing front gear to fold. Must be glued to main piece.

title: Great Northern Popcorn Flap Closing Widget

description.text: This widget is designed for a Great Northern popcorn machine.  I have an 8 oz, not sure if it will fit others.  It's designed to loosely sit on top of the stirrer collar and bump the metal flaps down if they get stuck up.  If the flap provides sharp resistance, the piece is designed to slide up the shaft of the stirrer to not damage the flap.  The widget has little arms that grip the shaft to prevent it from falling off when you dump the kettle.

remixed_from.title: Customizable bit holder for 1/4" hex drive bits

title: Customizable *non-3D-printed* 1/4" bit holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: I know this place is all about some 3D printing, and I even made a 3D-printable version of this concept, but I wanted a 1/4" hex bit holder larger than my 3D printer's build area, and besides, the time spent actually fabricating this thing was way less than a 3D print would have been. Basically, I've uploaded a Python script that takes a spreadsheet that you can edit in Excel or whatever (saved in CSV format) as input, and it produces a PDF suitable for printing. The spreadsheet describes the bits you want to store and the sizing for the holder. You print it, glue it to some 3/4" plywood or MDF, drill the holes where marked, and boom -- bit holder customized to your exact needs. The script requires Python 3.x and the Pyx library. (Note: My version looks a bit different from the published defaults, because I realized after making mine that the larger sockets made more sense in the back.) (The PS file included is to satisfy the Thingiverse rules robot, since it doesn't think a "PDF" can describe a Thing.)

The script will generate a PDF suitable for gluing onto a piece of wood, so you can drill holes where marked, and store 1/4" bits in labeled spots.
  • Configure by editing the CSV (comma-separated values) file in any spreadsheet software (Excel, OpenOffice Calc, etc.). See the CSV itself for format details.
  • Run the script:
    python bitstorage.py [infile.csv] [outfile.pdf]
  • Print the resulting PDF.
  • Use a thin coat of wood glue to affix it to some 3/4" plywood or MDF. Let it dry.
  • Cut the wood+label out along the lines with your saw of choice (jigsaw, circular saw, band saw -- I prefer the latter). You can even use a manual saw if you have to.
  • Prepare a drill or drill press with an appropriate drill bit. From best to worst, I recommend 19/64", 5/16", 7.5mm, or 8mm.
  • We need to limit the depth of the hole to about 5/8" (~15mm). If using a drill press, set the depth limiter. If using a hand drill, put some tape on the bit about that far up.
  • Drill on every circled X, stopping at the appropriate depth.
  • Blow it off, clean it up, and insert bits. You're done.
    • NOTE: The script requires Python 3.x and the Pyx library.

comments.text: Don't worry about it not being a 3-d printed file. This is thingiverse new ideas are welcome. I really like this concept. I'm not too familiar with python. Is there a simple way to remove the "x" in the circles or change the font color to white on the X. I would like to be able to use a laser cutter to  to engrave on the material rather than glue on a cutout.

Alula inspired free flight glider. 1/5th scale. Glides well.

PLA
2 shells
.2mm layer height
standard PLA setting Simplify 3D:
100% infill to get nose weight Snap together, leading edge first then bend the trailing edge to slide in to tail. After assembly you may need to put some reflex in the elevons. IE lift the trailing edge of both wings a bit. Also adjust either the left or right elevon to fix roll issues. IE left trailing edge up if it rolls right and right trailing edge up if it rolls left. Update:
Added wing v4 and tail V4 which moves the center of gravity more forward and is easier to adjust post printing. Glides more stable. Added launch point to fuse for use with rubberband. Also print both parts, wing and pod at 100% infill. If you feel the glider is nose heavy, print with less than 100% infill

comments.text: Mine was WAY tail heavy but then I used only 15% infill and sorted the rest with screws.. a rocket later and she went like a beauty

comments.text:

Added launch point to fuse for use with rubberband, the added weight also helps with stability.

Lately, there have been a lot of spool holders posted on Thingiverse. I promised others on Thingiverse that I'd post this last week. It's been stress-tested for several months now and is ready for primetime. Here is the second version of my original filament spool system with significant advantages. First, it's 100% printable. No hardware is needed for either the mount or the actual spool! The entire spool and mounting hardware can be printed on a Cupcake / ToM from only two .stl plates, and only four prints. Its standard size is ideal for 1lb rolls of plastic and has been tested with ultimaker and MBI rolls. Even if you order 5 lb rolls, unless you print constantly, you probably should cut it into smaller bundles since the hydrophilic plastic will absorb moisture. The spool mounts to the side of the Cupcake (I don't have a ToM but expect it would work too) with friction-fit clips. A PTFE tube to act as a guide for the filament is optional but recommended (I have successfully printed about 3 lbs of plastic both with, and without, the guide tube). The spindle can be removed by squeezing the bird's mouth tabs on the end of the spindle post and pulling the hub off. The hub and filament can be placed into a plastic bag (without removing the filament) to allow it to remain dry when not printing). The hooks that hold the filament have clips that hold the tail end of your filament (to prevent the filament from tangling) and to clip the working end when it's removed for storage. The design is almost fully parametric, so you can print different sized hubs and clips for different spool diameters and filament sizes (I've tried 3mm and 1.75mm). I originally used bearings on the hub but found that it is TOO low of friction, causing the spool to free-run and spooling off too much plastic. Although you can use bearings, some tension is necessary. The spindle post includes code to print a spring tensioner as shown in the photos. The stl's can be printed as is, but if you want to make parametric designs from the OpenSCAD file, also download Libs.scad from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:6021 as it has required modules.

1- For standard 1lb. rolls of 3mm filament, just print one copy of the HubSet.stl and three copies of ArmSet.stl. For additional rolls (where the spindle post and tube guides are not needed), print one copy of Hub.stl instead of the hub set.
2- Snap extension arms and arm ends into hub.
3- Snap two of the three hooks into the arm ends and place your filament on the two hooks.
4- Wrap the third hook around the filament bundle and snap it into the third arm end.
5- Mount the completed spool onto the hub post, which I chose to attach to the left side of the bot.
6- Route the filament through the (optional) PTFE tubing or tube guides and into the extruder. The standard stl's work well for me, but if you need different sizes, change the parameters in the scad file.

comments.text: Thanks for the spool.  I love it.  My trick to get the dovetails together was to use my soldering iron with a flat tip.  Just a little heat on the female dovetail can go a long way.  I pressed the dovetails together while warm and they are now practically glued together since cooling off.  I probably won't be able to take them apart again, but that's better than being too loose.
comments.author: nerdbot2085

comments.text: I'm glad you like it so far. I hope it works well for you. It is a VERY tight fit for me too but that is intentional to provide rigidity. For me, I'd get them started by getting the widest male part into the slot then with firm pressure against my bench almost rotate th male half down to engage it's full profile. Then use a mallet to get it flush. I have slight whitening in the corners of the slot from stretching but I've made 9 arms and haven't broken one yet. If you want to make the pin smaller you can edit the OpenSCAD file. No secret profile stuff here. Just a bigger hammer. I'd recommend against sanding the pin or slot since the layer ridges help to snap fit it in place.

title: Spiral Stairs going Down for RPGs

description.text:
Open Forge, Dwarven Forge, Dungeonstone, and Hirst Arts compatible 2" x 2" downward spiral stair pieces. They are textured mostly like the gothic floor/wall pieces from Hirst Arts than anything, though the texture is custom-made by me. The height is compatible with Dwarven Forge pieces, and is approximately 11/32" high on the "regular floor" portion.  
This thing includes both types of stairs, so you can print whichever (or both) as needed for your dungeons.  
It's the perfect compliment to Open Forge (and the others) to make it clear to your players that a set of stairs actually goes down rather than up.  
Enjoy!
Created in 3DS Max. Then cleaned up in netfabb basic, and then with Microsoft's free STL repair tool.

title: BQ Prusa i3 Z axis screw support

description.text: If, like me, you have a BQ Prusa i3 you'll probably see the Z axis screws wobble and maybe even hear squeaking sounds on large Z axis moves. Well, I designed this little "top hat" to support the Z axis screw by clipping it to the 8mm smooth rod. It fits into the space of the top supports and dose not reduce the print envelope. It reduces the wobble and stops any squeaking sounds. As usual the .STL, .STEP and .IGS files are available for all your modifying needs. Enjoy :) Please check out my Youtube video showing the Z axis noise and my design process for this part. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NmRy-vdtI-I Oh, you'll need to print 2 of course.
You'll need to print 2 of these, 1 for each Z axis screw.
